title: Use of Recombinant Fusion Proteins in a Fluorescent Protease Assay Platform and Their In-gel Renaturation
procedures:
1. Generation of the substrate-coding expression plasmids
Linearize the pDest-His6-MBP-FP expression plasmid by PacI and NheI restriction endonucleases. For the generation of pDest-His6-MBP-FP, see Bozóki et al.14.
	
Add 1,500-2,000 µg of pDest-His6-MBP-FP expression plasmid, 2 µL each of PacI and NheI restriction endonucleases, 10 µL of 10x buffer (see Table of Materials), and nuclease-free water (NFW) to 100 µL in a microcentrifuge tube.
Incubate the reaction mixture at 37 °C for 1 h.
Add 20 µL of 6x DNA purple loading dye to the reaction mixture and separate the cleavage products by electrophoresis, using 1% agarose gel. Apply a 1 kB DNA ladder as standard.
Rinse the gel for 15 min in 20 mL of TAE buffer (40 mM Tris, 20 mM acetic acid, 1 mM EDTA, pH 8.5) containing 20 µL of SYBR green solution and excise the band of the linearized plasmid out of the agarose gel, using a sharp tool.
	NOTE: While illuminating the gel by a dark-reading blue transilluminator (DRBT), the linearized pDest-His6-MBP-FP plasmid appears as a discrete and bright band at around 7-8 kB.
Purify the linearized expression plasmid from the gel slice by using a gel extraction kit according to the manufacturer's instructions.
Insert the substrate sequence into the linearized pDest-His6-MBP-FP expression plasmid.
	
Anneal the forward (FWD) and the reverse (REV) E. coli codon-optimized oligonucleotide primers coding for the substrate sequence of interest.
		NOTE: The annealed primers will be flanked by the cohesive ends corresponding to PacI and NheI restriction endonuclease cleavage sites (Figure 2).
		
Mix 150 ng of linearized expression plasmid with 200 ng of FWD and 200 ng of REV oligonucleotide primers in a 0.2 mL polymerase chain reaction (PCR) tube and adjust the volume to 17 µL by adding NFW.

Incubate the mixture at 65 °C for 2 min and, then, at 4 °C for at least 2 min.
Perform the insertion of the annealed primers into the linearized plasmid by ligation.
		
Add 2 µL of T4 ligase buffer (10x) and 1 µL of T4 ligase to the mixture containing the linearized plasmid and the annealed primers.
Incubate the ligation mixture at 16 °C for 16 h.

Transform 100 µL of BL21(DE3) competent cells by 5 µL of ligation mixture and spread the cells on lysogeny broth (LB) agar plates containing ampicillin.
	​NOTE: The fluorescent proteins will be in the same open reading frame with the N-terminal fusion tags only after a successful ligation. A few days after transformation, the colonies (containing the expression plasmid coding for the inserted cleavage site of interest) will show visible fluorescence with or even without using a DRBT.
Prepare glycerol stock from the depicted colonies.
	
Wash a discrete colony into a 50 mL centrifuge tube containing 5 µL of LB medium containing ampicillin (at a final concentration of 100 µg/mL).
Incubate it at 37 °C for 8 h while continuously shaking at 220 rpm; then, harvest the cells by centrifugation at 1,000 x g for 5 min at room temperature.
Gently suspend the cells in 1 mL of 80% glycerol solution (diluted with distilled water) and add 500 µL of 10 mM MgCl2 solution to the suspension.

Transfer the suspension to a freezing tube and store the stocks at -70 °C.
Verify the sequence of the generated plasmid by DNA sequencing.
	
Add 10 µL of the glycerol stock (prepared in step 1.7) to 5 mL of LB medium containing 100 µg/mL ampicillin in a 50 mL centrifuge tube.
Incubate the suspension at 37 °C for 16 h while continuously shaking at 220 rpm; then, harvest the cells by centrifugation at 2,000 x g for 10 min at 4 °C.
Isolate the expression plasmid from the cell pellet by a plasmid miniprep kit (see Table of Materials) according to the manufacturer's instructions, and use the purified plasmid for DNA sequencing.
		NOTE: For sequencing, 5'-GATGAAGCCCTGAAAGACGCGCAG-3' (forward) and 5'-GCAAGGCGATTAAGTTGGGTAACGC-3' (reverse) oligonucleotide primers may be used.
2. Expression of the fluorescent substrates
Prepare the starter culture.
	
Add 10 µL of the glycerol stock (prepared in step 1.7) to 5 mL of LB medium containing 100 µg/mL ampicillin in a 50 mL centrifuge tube.
Incubate the suspension at 37 °C for 15 h while continuously shaking at 220 rpm.
Transfer the bacterial culture (5 mL) to 50 mL of fresh LB medium containing 100 µg/mL ampicillin in a 500 mL sterile Erlenmeyer flask.
Grow the cells at 37 °C to an absorbance of 0.6-0.8 at a 600 nm wavelength, while continuously shaking at 220 rpm.
	NOTE: If a tetracycline treatment is to be applied at step 2.5, it is not recommended to grow the cells to an absorbance of more than 0.6 at 600 nm.
Add isopropyl β-D-1-thiogalactopyranoside (IPTG) to the 1 mM final concentration to induce protein expression.

If a tetracycline treatment is NOT applied, incubate the culture for 3 h at 37 °C while continuously shaking at 220 rpm and continue the protocol with step 2.6. If a tetracycline treatment is applied, continue the protocol with steps 2.5.1-2.5.3.
	NOTE: Some FPs produced by E. coli cells may have a longer maturation time (see previous work)16,17; in these cases, the protein translation can be optionally arrested by the tetracycline treatment, in order to increase the fluorescent yield of the substrate solution.
	
Incubate the cell suspension for 2 h at 37 °C while continuously shaking at 220 rpm; then, add a tetracycline solution (at a final concentration of 200 µg/mL).
Incubate the cell culture according to the maturation time of the fluorescent protein of choice at 37 °C, while continuously shaking at 220 rpm.
Transfer 2 x 25 mL of the culture to clean 50 mL centrifuge tubes and harvest the cells by centrifugation at 4,000 x g for 15 min at 4 °C.
Discard the supernatant and store the bacterial cell pellets at -70 °C for at least 1 h.
	NOTE: Cells containing the expressed fluorescent substrates show visible fluorescence with or even without using a DRBT.
3. Cell disruption
Place the frozen cell pellet on ice and let it thaw for 15 min.
Add 2 mL of lysis buffer (50 mM NaH2PO4, 300 mM NaCl, 10 mM imidazole, 0.05% Tween 20, pH 8) to the pellet and suspend the cells.
Add 10 µL of freshly prepared phenylmethanesulfonyl-fluoride (PMSF) protease inhibitor solution (8.7 mg/mL, dissolved in ethanol) to the suspension.
Add 2 mg of lysozyme and 20 units of DNase to the suspension and suspend it.
Incubate the suspension on ice for 15 min, and vortex it occasionally.

Transfer 2 x 1 mL of the suspension to 1.5 mL microcentrifuge tubes and sonicate the suspensions for 3 min, in rounds of 10 s of sonication and 5 s of resting.
Centrifuge the tubes at 10,000 x g for 20 min at room temperature; then, remove the fluorescent supernatant (cleared bacterial cell lysate) carefully from each tube and transfer it to new microcentrifuge tubes.
	NOTE: Cleared lysates containing the fluorescent substrate show visible fluorescence with or even without using a DRBT and can be stored at 4 °C for up to 2 weeks. Do NOT freeze it. Cleared lysates can be utilized directly for sample preparation in the protease assay (see section 4.1) or also can be used for substrate purification (see step 4.5.1).
4. Ni-NTA magnetic-bead-based protease assay
NOTE: Due to the flexibility of the assay platform, it can be optimized to many different types of studies. For this reason and due to the difference in the activity rate of the enzymes of choice, some of the assay parameters (where it is denoted) cannot be explicitly described but need to be optimized to the individual aims and experimental design. As a guidance, parameters of some types of studies are denoted at the particular steps.
Sample preparation
Generation of substrate-attached magnetic beads
Place a closed 2 mL low-protein-binding (see Table of Materials) microcentrifuge tube containing new or recycled (see section 4.7) Ni-NTA magnetic agarose beads in a magnetic particle concentrator (MPC).
			NOTE: The amount of the applied bead suspension is to be set based on the experimental design. We used 1 mL of magnetic bead solution (5%, v/v) at each experiment.

Beads may stick to the wall and/or into the lid of the microcentrifuge tube; therefore, turn the MPC upside-down in every direction to make sure that all of the beads are collected.
Remove the supernatant and discard it.
Wash the beads by lysis buffer.
			
Add 1.8 mL of lysis buffer to the beads and remove the closed tube from the MPC.
Suspend the beads in the tube by shaking and/or turning the tubes upside-down until the sample is completely homogeneous.
Place the tube back into the MPC and turn it upside-down to collect the beads.
Open the tube and discard the supernatant.
Add 1.0-1.8 mL of the cleared lysate (prepared in step 3.7) to the beads and remove the tube from the MPC.
Turn the closed tube upside-down until the beads are completely homogeneous and slowly rotate the tube by a rotator at room temperature for 30 min.
Place it into the MPC and remove the cleared cell lysate from the beads and from the lid.
			NOTE: The cleared cell lysate may be discarded or saved for further use (see the note after step 3.7).
Add 1% Tween 20 (pH 7) to the substrate-attached magnetic beads (SAMBs).
			NOTE: SAMBs show visible fluorescence with or even without using a DRBT.
Washing of the SAMBs
Place the tube with the SAMB suspension into the MPC and discard the supernatant.
Wash the SAMBs 3x with each buffer: i) 1.8 mL of 1% Tween 20 (pH 7); ii) 1.8 mL of washing buffer (50 mM NaH2PO4, 300 mM NaCl, 5 mM imidazole, 0.05% Tween 20, pH 7); iii) 1.8 mL of cleavage buffer (50 mM NaH2PO4, 300 mM NaCl, 0.05% Tween 20, pH 7).

NOTE: For the washing procedure, see step 4.1.1.4. The cleavage buffer may be changed according to the experimental needs, but it is recommended to check the manual of the Ni-NTA magnetic beads to determine compatibility.
Preparation of the SAMB stock solution
Add a cleavage buffer to the washed SAMBs to create a SAMB stock solution.
			NOTE: After the addition of the buffer, DO NOT shake or turn the tube upside-down. The volume of the cleavage buffer depends on the individual experimental design and must be calculated based on the number of magnetic beads (see step 4.1.1.1) and on the volumes to be used in step 4.1.4.2. For 2 mL tubes, the applied volume is up to 1,900 µL (see Table 1). The recommended magnetic bead density of the SAMB stock solution is 2%-10% (v/v).

Prepare the proteolytic enzyme solution according to the experimental needs.
		NOTE: It is recommended to use a cleavage buffer to dissolve and/or dilute the enzyme. Protocols for the purification of HIV-114 and TEV PRs18 have been published previously.
Set the thermoshaker's agitation rate (600 rpm) and incubation temperature (Table 6).

Termination of the proteolytic reactions
Take the sample out of the shaker, 30 s prior to the end of incubation, and spin it promptly.
Place the tube onto the MPC, let it stand for 15 s, and slightly move the MPC back and forth.
Open the lid and transfer the supernatant carefully to a plate or a new tube.
		NOTE: Do not touch the concentrated beads with the tip of the pipette. The collected supernatant of C samples and R samples with a high degree of cleavage may show visible fluorescence with or even without the using of a DRBT.
Fluorescent detection
Transfer 2 x 30 µL of the separated sample supernatants to a black half-area microplate.
Measure the fluorescence using the appropriate excitation and emission filters.
		NOTE: Measure the basic fluorescence of the cleavage buffer and elution buffer, as well. Filter combinations need to be chosen based on the measured fluorescent protein (Table 9).

Calibration
	NOTE: To generate calibration curves in step 4.6.1, fluorescence intensity values of cleavage- or elution-buffer-solved purified substrates at different concentrations need to be measured.
	
Purify the fluorescent substrates.

NOTE: For purification, SAMBs of the substrate blank (B) samples after the protease assay may be collected, or a new SAMB suspension can also be prepared (see sections 4.1.1 and 4.1.2).
		
Place a tube with SAMBs suspended in 1 mL of cleavage buffer (2%-10%; v/v) to the MPC and collect the magnetic beads by turning the MPC upside-down in every direction.
Open the tube and remove the cleavage buffer, both from the tube and the lid.
Remove the tube from the MPC and add 400-600 µL of elution buffer to the SAMBs.
Slowly rotate the closed tube with a rotator at room temperature for 5 min.
Place the tube onto the MPC and collect the beads by turning the MPC upside-down.
Remove the supernatant containing the purified intact fluorescent substrate (eluate) and transfer it to a new low-protein-binding microcentrifuge tube.
			NOTE: Eluate shows clearly visible fluorescence with or even without using a DRBT.
Perform parallel buffer exchange by using two 0.5 mL 10K ultrafiltration devices.
		
Measure half volume of the prepared eluate (200-300 µL) into each ultrafiltration device.
After at each centrifugation step, dilute the concentrated eluate in the first and the second ultrafiltration devices by elution buffer and cleavage buffer, respectively.
After the recovery, adjust the concentrated samples solved in the different buffers to the same volume, between 120-200 µL.
			NOTE: Now the protein content of the cleavage buffer-solved substrate is identical to the elution buffer-solved substrate; therefore, it is not necessary to determine the protein content of the latter one at step 4.5.3, if the method used for measuring protein concentration interferes with EDTA.
Determine the protein content of the substrates dissolved either in elution or cleavage buffer by measuring the absorbance at 280 nm.

NOTE: Other methods (e.g., Bradford or bicinchoninic acid (BCA) assays) may also be used to measure protein concentration, but possible interference with EDTA (present in the elution buffer) or with the absorbance of the fluorescent substrate needs to be considered. The initial protein content of the substrate solution to be applied in step 4.5.4 is recommended to be between 0.4-2.0 mg/mL in order to generate a calibration curve in an appropriate range. See Table 10 for extinction coefficients.

Prepare a twofold serial dilution in at least eight steps, both from the elution- and from the cleavage-buffer-solved substrate solutions, using elution or cleavage buffer for the dilution, respectively.
Transfer 30 µL of each dilution point to a black half-area microplate.
Measure the fluorescence with a fluorimeter, using the setting applied in step 4.4.2.
		NOTE: Measure the basic fluorescence of both the cleavage and the elution buffer.
Evaluation of the assay
Plot the calibration curves.
		
Calculate the concentration (in mM) of the purified substrate solutions (used in step 4.5.4), based on the protein content determined in step 4.5.3.
Correct the relative fluorescence intensity values (RFU) of the serial dilution points by the basic RFU values of the applied dilution buffer (the cleavage buffer or the elution buffer).
Plot the corrected RFU values against the molar concentration of the cleavage- or elution-buffer-solved purified substrates and perform a linear regression (force the intercept to zero).

NOTE: A high R2 value (˃0.97) indicates a good linear correlation between the fluorescence and the concentration of the fluorescent protein. In this case, the slope of the regression line can be used to assess the concentration of the assay components in the examined range in steps 4.6.2 and 4.6.3. Experimental errors and data point distribution may affect the reliability of the calibration; thus, a graphical evaluation may be performed with the help of zoom-in graphs (as shown in Figure 3), in order to check whether R2 and the slope values are influenced by the data.
Calculate the amount of C-terminal fluorescent cleavage product in the reaction samples.
		
Correct the RFU values of each R sample with the RFU values of the corresponding B sample.
Calculate the cleavage product concentration (in mM) in the reaction samples by dividing the corrected RFU values by the slope of the cleavage-buffer-based calibration curve (see step 4.6.1.3).
Calculate the applied substrate concentration in the reaction samples.
		
Correct the RFU values of the C sample with the RFU value of the basic elution buffer.
Calculate the concentration of the eluted substrate (in mM) in the supernatants of the C sample by dividing their corrected RFU values by the slope of the elution-buffer-based calibration curve (see step 4.6.1.3).
Determine the substrate concentration (in mM) of the SAMB stock solution used for creating the assay samples in step 4.1.4.2, based on the following equation:

​Here, cSAMB is the molar concentration of the SAMB stock solution prepared at section 4.1.3; cC is the molar concentration of the eluted substrate in the C sample calculated at step 4.6.3.3; Vr is the volume of the reaction mixture created by the addition of the reaction buffer in step 4.1.4.5 and the enzyme buffer in step 4.2.3.; and VSAMB is the volume of the SAMB stock solution in the C sample (step 4.1.4.2).
Calculate the molar concentration of the substrates in each R sample based on the molar concentration of the SAMB stock solution (in mM) according to the volume (in µL) measured in each reaction sample tube at step 4.1.4.2.
Perform data processing.
		NOTE: The data analysis depends on the aim of the experiment. The video shows an example for data processing of a substrate-dependent kinetic study on HIV-1 PR using His6-MBP-VSQNY*PIVQ-mTurquoise2 substrate. The initial velocity values are calculated from the number of C-terminal cleavage fragments and are plotted against the applied substrate concentration. The kinetic parameters are determined by a Michaelis-Menten nonlinear regression analysis.
Recycling of the magnetic beads
	NOTE: After performing an assay, the magnetic agarose beads can be collected and recycled.
	
Collect the used magnetic beads with the MPC and discard the supernatant.
		
Wash the beads with 1.8 mL of the following buffers, in the order given: regeneration buffer A (0.05% Tween 20, 0.5 M NaOH), regeneration buffer B (0.05% Tween 20), regeneration buffer C (0.05% Tween 20, 100 mM EDTA, pH 8), regeneration buffer B, regeneration buffer D (0.05% Tween 20, 100 mM NiSO4, pH 8), regeneration buffer B, and regeneration buffer E (0.5% Tween 20, 30% ethanol, pH 7).
			NOTE: For the washing procedure, see step 4.1.1.4.
Store the recycled beads in regeneration buffer E at 4 °C.
5. PAGE analysis
Sample preparation

NOTE: After performing the Ni-NTA magnetic-bead-based assay, the assay supernatants can be analyzed by PAGE. In this case, skip steps 5.1.1 and 5.1.2. However, it is also possible to analyze the purified fluorescent substrates solution and/or their cleavage fragments after in-solution digestion with the protease of interest. In this case, continue the protocol with step 5.1.1.
	
Prepare the purified fluorescent substrate solution according to step 4.5.1.
Perform in-solution digestion.
		
Exchange elution buffer with cleavage buffer in the 0.5 mL 10K ultrafiltration device and aliquot the samples to be digested into 1.5 mL microcentrifuge tubes.
			NOTE: For the PAGE analysis, we aliquoted 68 µL of each substrate, but the number of sample tubes and the volume of substrate solution to be aliquoted can be optimized according to the individual experimental design.
Add the enzyme solution to the samples.
			NOTE: For the PAGE analysis, we applied 2 µL of HIV-1 PR, prepared as described by Bozóki et al.14, but the volume may be optimized according to the individual experimental design. It is recommended to use cleavage buffer to dissolve and/or dilute the enzyme.
Incubate the samples according to the experimental design.
			NOTE: For the PAGE analysis, we incubated the reaction mixture for 45 min at 37 °C, but the incubation time and temperature need to be set according to the experimental design.
Terminate the reaction by performing step 5.1.3.
Prepare the sample for PAGE.
		NOTE: The fluorescent-substrate-containing samples may be prepared for the PAGE by a nondenaturing or by a denaturing method. For the use of nondenaturing or denaturing conditions, follow step 5.1.3.1 or 5.1.3.2, respectively.
		
Prepare a nondenatured sample: mix 30 µL of the sample with 6 µL of 6x nondenaturing sample-loading buffer (300 mM Tris, 20% glycerol, 0.05% bromophenol blue, pH 6.8).

Prepare a denatured sample: mix 30 µL of the sample with 6 µL of 6x denaturing sample-loading buffer (300 mM Tris, 20% glycerol, 0.05% bromophenol blue, 12% SDS, 100 mM β-mercaptoethanol, pH 6.8), and heat the samples at 95 °C for 10 min.
SDS-PAGE analysis
	NOTE: Optionally, if only nondenatured (prepared in step 5.1.3.1) samples are to be analyzed, a native PAGE can also be performed. In this case, skip section 5.3.
	
Prepare an SDS-polyacrylamide gel (use 14% separating and 4% stacking gel) and fill the tank with electrophoresis buffer (2.5 mM Tris, 19.2 mM glycine, 0.01% SDS).
Add the samples (prepared in step 5.1.3.1 or 5.1.3.2) to the wells of a polyacrylamide gel and perform electrophoresis at 120 V voltage.
Remove the gel cassette from the running module and place the gel into a washing tank.
		NOTE: Nondenatured samples are already visible in the gel, even by the naked eye or with a DRBT.
In-gel renaturation and detection of fluorescent proteins
	NOTE: To detect the fluorescent proteins in denatured samples (prepared in step 5.1.3.2) on the DRBT, SDS needs to be washed out from the gel, to partially renature the proteins.
	
Add ~100 mL of distilled water to the gel and rinse the gel at least for 30 min.
		NOTE: To improve the SDS removal, replace the water every 10 min, or rinse up to 60 min.
Visualize the fluorescent proteins by using a DRBT, or by UV imaging.
Conventional Coomassie staining of the gel
Stain the gel with Coomassie Brilliant Blue dye to visualize nonfluorescent proteins.
